Line 273: Line 273:
===Kuwait===
===Kuwait===
â
In a move seen by some as attempt to head off economic issues as a cause for unrest, [[Emir of Kuwait]] Sheikh [[Sabah Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah]] gave all "its citizens [1.12 million people] free food rations and a grant of $4,000 [1,000 dinars]."<ref>{{cite news|title=After the Revolution, Economic Reform|publisher=Wall Street Journal|author=Carl Schramm|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704268104576107660043625644.html|date=2011-02-02}}</ref> Officially the grant is in commemoration of "the 20th anniversary of Kuwait's liberation from occupying Iraqi forces and which also marks the 50th anniversary of the state's independence."<ref name="Kuwait">{{cite news|title=Kuwaitisâ Free Food Grant to Cost $818 Million|publisher=KUNA Reports|author=Dahlia Kholaif|date=Jan 17, 2011|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-18/kuwaitis-free-food-grant-to-cost-818-million-kuna-reports.html}}</ref> The cost of the food is estimated at 230 million dinars ($818 million) and will be available from February 1, 2011, to March 31, 2012.<ref name="Kuwait"/> Opposition groups called for protests on March 8,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/02/14/clashes-bahrain-planned-protest-rally/?test=latestnews |title=Clashes in Bahrain before planned protest rally |publisher=FoxNews.com |date=2010-02-01 |accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref> and dozens of stateless Arabs demonstrated in Kuwait on February 19.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://online.wsj.com/video/stateless-arabs-demonstrate-in-kuwait/CAE0DC2D-AFEA-4036-BD8E-FCE980F21B9B.html?mod=WSJ_Article_Videocarousel_1 | work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref>
+
In a move seen by some as attempt to head off economic issues as a cause for unrest, [[Emir of Kuwait]] Sheikh [[Sabah Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah]] gave all "its citizens [1.12 million people] free food rations and a grant of $4,000 [1,000 dinars]."<ref>{{cite news|title=After the Revolution, Economic Reform|publisher=Wall Street Journal|author=Carl Schramm|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704268104576107660043625644.html|date=2011-02-02}}</ref> Officially the grant is in commemoration of "the 20th anniversary of Kuwait's liberation from occupying Iraqi forces and which also marks the 50th anniversary of the state's independence."<ref name="Kuwait">{{cite news|title=Kuwaitisâ Free Food Grant to Cost $818 Million|publisher=KUNA Reports|author=Dahlia Kholaif|date=Jan 17, 2011|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-18/kuwaitis-free-food-grant-to-cost-818-million-kuna-reports.html}}</ref> The cost of the food is estimated at 230 million dinars ($818 million) and will be available from February 1, 2011, to March 31, 2012.<ref name="Kuwait"/> {{Who|date=February 2011}}Opposition groups called for protests on March 8,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/02/14/clashes-bahrain-planned-protest-rally/?test=latestnews |title=Clashes in Bahrain before planned protest rally |publisher=FoxNews.com |date=2010-02-01 |accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref> and dozens of stateless Arabs demonstrated in Kuwait on February 19.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://online.wsj.com/video/stateless-arabs-demonstrate-in-kuwait/CAE0DC2D-AFEA-4036-BD8E-FCE980F21B9B.html?mod=WSJ_Article_Videocarousel_1 | work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref>
